data.title: Add method to import resources in the editor via a file select dialog.

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
### Summary

Currently, the only method of importing a resource in the Duality editor is via dragging-and-dropping a file into the Project View. Consider adding an alternative method of importing, via a file selection dialog.

### Analysis

#### Benefits
- Allows importing of resources in scenarios where file drag-and-drop may be unavailable.
- Makes the editor more accessible to touchpad users (drag-and-drop is kind of hard to do with a touchpad).

#### Feature Access
- Could be accessed through a tool button on the Project View.
- Might also be accessible through an option in the right-click context menu in the Project View.

#### Implementation Ideas
- The file select dialog would presumably open to the project's root folder at first launch.
- In subsequent launches, would it perhaps be possible for it to open at the folder that was last open in the dialog?

data.title: Streamline Scene / GameObjectManager Implementation

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
### Summary

Most of the current Scene implementations object management is based on per-object operations and event subscriptions. Using per-batch-of-objects operations seems preferable with regard to both performance and API.

### Analysis

- Replace per-object API of GameObjectManager class with per-batch-of-objects API.
  - Every batch of objects will be treated as one entity with regard to init and shutdown of its parts.
  - Different batches of objects will be treated independently of each other.
- Update Scene implementation to reflect this.
- Update code introduced in issue #303 to make use of the improvements made here.
  - Fix component exec order for cases where a GameObject tree is added to or removed from an already active scene and activate the two unit tests related to this.
  - Currently works on a per-GameObject basis, not on a per-Tree basis due to lack of control with the old API.

data.title: SpriteRenderer Flip Horizontal Conflict with RigidBody Rotation

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
### Summary

When you have a SpriteRenderer attached to a RigidBody, and the Flip property is set to Horizontal, if the RigiBody rotates the sprite does it in the opposite direction.

### How to reproduce [Bugs]

- Add a GameObject
- Add a SpriteRenderer to the GameObject.
- Add a RigidBody to the GameObject.
- Change the RigidBody's angular velocity and press play to see it working.
- Change the Flip property of the SpriteRenderer to Horizontal.
- Press play to see the bug.

### Attachments

https://gfycat.com/ParallelBlushingBlacknorwegianelkhound

data.title: Overhaul GameObject API

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
### Summary

The public GameObject API carries some methods that are almost never used, perform poorly, or provide questionable functionality - such as finding child objects by name. Investigate potential improvements as part of the v3.0 milestone.

### Analysis

- Improve performance
  - Where possible, replace iterators with more efficient means of enumerating objects.
  - Introduce shortcuts and exploit internal field access where opportunity arises, if that would be more efficient.
- Remove questionable API
  - Consider removing find-by-name functionality.
  - Consider removing IterateXY functionality and instead provide more efficient Get/Children/Deep methods. Provide the option to retrieve these objects sorted by exec order, internally exploiting knowledge about pre-sorted lists to improve efficiency.
  - Investigate other questionable functionality or API.
- Streamline existing functionality
  - To be investigated as well.

### Auto-Expand for TreeViewAdv. Issue #492.

I went with the approach to extend TreeViewAdv and used the new class in both ProjectFolderView and SceneView. I tried to keep the changes as minimal as possible although the solution and csproj seem to have run away from a simple add existing file, let me know if I should remove them.

A few questions\comments:

1. Do you want to keep consistency of the type held by the SceneView\ProjectFolderView? I have currently kept the type as TreeViewAdv and just newed it to the new type (AutoExpandTreeView) which has a default of 1000 ms delay.

2. Is there a place to provide user\editor preferences, I would suggest putting the delay as an option for users. 

3. Have fun reviewing <3

4. Should I add automated testing?

data.title: Make Scenes Self-Contained

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
### Summary

Duality is hardwired to always have one active Scene and some of its code is built on that assumption. Gradually move away from this by making Scenes self-contained / independent classes as a first step.

### Analysis

- Internally, all Scenes share a single static physics `World`. Replace this with a Scene-local instance that is created on-demand and cleared / re-used.
- Rename `scene.IsCurrent` to `IsActive` to clear the way for future changes in behavior.
- Find all references to `Scene.Current` and evaluate whether they can be removed or replaced with `gameObj.ParentScene`.
- Make `Render` and `Update` API public and allow calling them when the Scene is not the `Current` one. 
  - Modify switch locking behavior to only trigger for the `Current` scene.
  - Write a unit test to verify whether Component methods for rendering and updates are properly called for non-`Current` scenes when called explicitly.
- Replace the static `OnLeaving` and `OnEntered` handlers with public `Activate` and `Deactivate` methods for the scene class, allowing to properly activate and deactivate a secondary / non-`Current` scene before calling update and render methods.
- When done, consider going a step further and extracting `SceneManager` functionality from `Scene` that would handle scene activity and (previously) static global events. This is a new issue that would have to be created afterwards.

data.title: Add Zoom Level Option to Tileset View

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
### Summary

Editing AutoTiles in the Tileset editor is difficult at tiny tile sizes. Although tiles under 24x24 are scaled up, on some displays, editing larger tiles than that is a challenge too.

### Workaround

Windows Magnifier

### Analysis

- The display size of the tiles in the tile editor could be modified arbitrarily
- ..with a pair of buttons on the toolbar,
- and by scrolling the mouse wheel (that's a standard way of resizing the view in many applications)

### Icons
`magnifier_zoom_in` and `magnifier_zoom_out` icons from the fatcow set could be used for the buttons.

data.title: Consider a Zero-Length-Safe Implementation of Vector2/3/4.Normalize/d

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
### Summary

Normalizing a zero-length vector is not a valid operation, leading to a (correct) `NaN` result vector. However, since normalizing vectors is a very common operation, writing correct code tends to introduce lots and lots of length checks all over the user code base and makes relying on `.Normalized` and `.Normalize()` near impractical. Consider an alternative implementation to counter this.

### Analysis

The options for reacting to a zero-length vector are the following:

#### NaN vector

-  Mathematically correct.
-  Useless in practice.
-  Viral.

#### Zero vector

-  Mathematically incorrect.
-  Can cause other calculations expecting unit lengths to produce `NaN` / `Infinity`.
-  Useful in practice.
-  Naturally represents "no direction".
-  Non-viral.

#### 0 unit-length vector

-  Mathematically incorrect.
-  Weird bias towards a specific direction.
-  Useful in practice.
-  Non-viral.

#### Throw an exception

-  Mathematically correct.
-  Makes it immediately obvious where the problem occurred...
-  ...but that knowledge can only be used to clutter code with more length checks.
-  Useless in practice.
-  Will crash the game for what often amounts to be insignificant large-scale.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Adams_Lair/status/830780767374557186) and community chat polls seem to favor the "Zero vector" variant.

data.title: Package Manager should map content folder to project root on non-Duality packages

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
Using my plugin as an example: it depends on `IronPython.StdLib`, which extracts a `Lib/` folder to the project root according to NuGet (`target="content/Lib"`). 

The issue here is that Duality maps all content inside `content` to the `Data` folder, which may not be desired for non-Duality packages (user would have access to package-related stuff inside Duality. Instead, Duality should just map `content` to the project root if the package is not related to Duality.

data.title: Log a Warning When Detecting Cyclig RequiredComponent Dependencies

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
### Summary

User-defined `RequiredComponent` dependencies can be cyclic. While currently detected and sorted out, this happens silently. Instead, there should be a warning in the log, as cyclic dependencies should be avoided and thus shouldn't go unnoticed.

### Analysis

- Probably can be done with some additional flags in `ComponentRequirementMap.TypeData`. Investigate.
- Back this up with unit tests.

data.title: Duality keeps recreating ProjectPlugins.

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
### Summary

In my case i have renamed my solution to 'Pathfindax'. This works fine except for the fact that duality keeps recreating the ProjectPlugins solution file and the CorePlugin folder. From what I have seen in the source code the name of the solution file seems to be hardcoded.

### How to reproduce

-Rename solution file to a different name
-Restart duality
-Notice the ProjectPlugins solution file has been recreated.

### Workaround

Not really a workaround but you can ignore it in visual studio/source control and pretend its not there.

### Analysis

A way to change the default hardcoded name of the solution file would prevent this

data.title: Refactor Shader / DrawTechnique Resources

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
### Summary

The current rendering resources related to shaders are needlessly convoluted: For a simple shader, the user needs to create a new FragmentShader, VertexShader, ShaderProgram and DrawTechnique resource, two of which don't really add a lot of value. Find a way to unify them.

### Analysis

This feature is very much wip / concept phase. Feedback and contributions to the thought process appreciated.

#### First Draft

- All four of the above resources could be unified into a single text-based drawing technique description file.
- The file format could simply consist of a flat list of sections, each with one parameter subsection and one shader subsection.
- There is one subsection per shader(-program) and one general subsection that is shared by all in both parameters and code.
  - Internally, every shader subsection is compiled into a distinct shader program.
  - Each program section must contain at least one of vertex or a fragment shader main functions, and can contain both, if both are needed.
  - The general section must not contain any main functions, but can contain shared code for all of the programs.
- Parameters include the blending mode to use, depth- and alpha test settings and similar.
  - Which function are main functions for vertex and fragment shaders is specified via parameter.
  - Custom parameters can be added to be evaluated by the core.
  - If a parameter is present in both the general section and a shader section, the value from the shader section will be used.
- Allow to specify "base techniques".
  - The general section will be merged with the current one's.
  - The shader sections will be included as-is.
  - Ideally, this would happen at the resource level (rename resources, etc.), but there could be a hint parameter in the source file that gets parsed by the importer to form a bridge.
- Whatever the format will look like in the end, it should not throw off syntax highlighters for GLSL, so they can still be used.

#### Benefits

- Unified file that fully describes how a material is rendered.
- Full overview in the text editor.
- Less noise in the Project View.
- Opportunity to easily sneak in shared base functionality.
- Potential for future multi-pass rendering of objects by specifying a `RenderStep` ID (or similar) per shader section and letting the graphics backend pick the appropriate one.

### Attachments

- Slightly related: issue #219

data.title: In the Editor, Initialize Textures With a Reasonable Size

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
### Summary

When creating a new Texture resource "from scratch" in the editor (without source Pixmap), it should be initialized with a reasonable default size, like `128x128`. 

### Analysis

- Initialize empty textures with a default size of `128x128`.
- Otherwise, it's quite easy to trip into errors thrown by other parts of the core, complaining about the zero-size texture.
- The setup shouldn't be done in the default constructor, but in an `EditorAction` with a setup context, like [this one](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/blob/066bfc5753dfabf895b391daa286787d28bf5185/Source/Plugins/EditorBase/EditorActions/SetupRigidBodyForEditing.cs). Instantiating new textures via source code should not imply allocating some arbitrary default space.
- Also, consider raising the editor hint min value for the [texture size property](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/blob/066bfc5753dfabf895b391daa286787d28bf5185/Source/Core/Duality/Resources/Texture.cs#L170) to one.

data.title: Introduce Explicit Vertex Buffers to the Graphics Backend Interface

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
### Summary

Right now, there is no concept of a vertex buffer in the "frontend" of Duality, all such details are managed by the graphics backend alone. However, for large, static meshes it would be useful to be able to explicitly upload a bit of vertex data into a VertexBuffer object and then use it (instead of a vertex array) in a specialized draw batch.

### Analysis

- `INativeVertexBuffer` interface definition.
- `NativeVertexBuffer` implementation in dummy and OpenGL backends.
- `VertexBuffer` convenience class implementation in the Duality core, wrapping around an `INativeVertexBuffer` and providing higher-level functionality.
- Move dynamic batching and vertex buffer management logic from the graphics backend to the "frontend", since there is no longer a reason to keep it there.
- Move dynamic batching logic into a distinct class, no need to keep it in `DrawDevice`.
- `IDrawBatch` implementation that uses a `VertexBuffer`.
- `IDrawDevice` API that allows specifying vertices using a `VertexBuffer`.

### Attachments

- Related to issue #395 
- Related to issue #326

data.title: Use Newline Chars in Text Formatting, Potentially Redesign Markup

milestone.title: Future
milestone.description: New systems and modules requiring a significant amount of long-term effort.

data.body:
### Summary

Currently duality is using /n as a newline character. This is a non standard way for newline characters. It would be better if it would follow the standard way:
- \n = LF (Line Feed) // Used as a newline character in Unix/Mac OS X
- \r\n = CR + LF // Used as a newline character in Windows

Environment.NewLine (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.environment.newline(v=vs.110).aspx) does exactly this

### Analysis

This would make it easier to work with newlines in duality since its using the standard way. On top of that it will be more consistent across different OS systems.

data.title: Move Drawcall Collection From Camera to RenderSetup

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
### Summary

The new `RenderSetup` resource is a big step towards customizable rendering pipelines, but there's still room for improvement as long as high-level rendering step handling and drawcall collection are hidden away in the `Camera` class. Move them over to `RenderSetup`. The camera's role will be to wrap an auto-configured draw device in a component, but no longer to perform actual rendering logic.

### Analysis

- **Goal:** Have the entire `RenderSingleStep` implementation in a virtual `RenderSetup` method.
  - Move `CollectDrawcalls` to `RenderSetup` in some way.
  - Things that are tied to Camera and need to be re-organized:
    - Picking
      - Could be moved into a new, custom `PickingRenderSetup` that also keeps track of the mapping and can take most of the picking code from Camera.
      - This is actually a nice cleanup opportunity.
      - There will be some additional design work to make sure that `PickingRenderSetup` could be used from outside `Camera`.
    - Editor Filters
      - Could provide a generic renderer filter method as part of the rendering setup API.
      - Since RenderSetup can already filter whatever it wants with this new design, they don't really have a good place in the API.
      - One way around this would by explicitly making them a "temporary" thing that is provided via parameter when invoking rendering functionality from the outside.
- **Goal:** Have the entire `RenderAllSteps` implementation in a virtual `RenderSetup` method.
- **Goal:** All `RenderSetup` functionality should be accessible from the outside, so others could theoretically implement custom `Camera` components.
  - Remove internal methods, make them public with a proper API.
